Name: Use of Invariant Value in Dynamically Changing Context
Description: The product uses a constant value, name, or reference, but this value can (or should) vary across different environments.

Entries.IntroText: The following code is an example of an internal hard-coded password in the back-end:

Entries.BodyText: Every instance of this program can be placed into diagnostic mode with the same password. Even worse is the fact that if this program is distributed as a binary-only distribution, it is very difficult to change that password or disable this "functionality."

Entries.IntroText: This code assumes a particular function will always be found at a particular address. It assigns a pointer to that address and calls the function.

Entries.BodyText: The same function may not always be found at the same memory address. This could lead to a crash, or an attacker may alter the memory at the expected address, leading to arbitrary code execution.

ObservedExamples.Description: Component for web browser writes an error message to a known location, which can then be referenced by attackers to process HTML/script in a less restrictive context
